htmlEmbed:
Where’s the safest place to live in the U.S., given the climate change crisis?The Washington Post8/1/2021

Post reporters Sarah Kaplan and Tik Root will answer your questions live on Thursday at 2 p.m. Eastern time.

Climate & EnvironmentRead

The proposed bill is $3.5 trillion. The article has been corrected.</p></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">When Hurricane Ida <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/weather/2021/08/29/hurricane-ida-live-updates/?itid=lk_inline_manual_3" target=_blank>made landfall on the coast of Louisiana</a> Sunday, the Category 4 hurricane was one of the most intense storms to hit the state. More than a million people lost power, entire towns were cut from communication and many have been left without clean water — or in some cases, water at all. Human-caused warming of the planet, experts say, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2021/08/29/how-climate-change-helped-make-hurricane-ida-one-louisianas-worst/?itid=lk_inline_manual_3" target=_blank>likely made the hurricane more powerful </a>than it otherwise would have been.</p></div></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><div class=" b bh bc-gray-lighter mb-md hide-for-print" data-qa="subscribe-promo"><a class="pt-sm pb-sm flex items-center bold font-xxxs font-xxs-ns offblack hover-blue-bright justify-between" href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2022/02/22/climate-change-actions-carbon-footprint/?itid=lk_cta_ssinline" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" style="border:none"><span class="mr-xs flex items-center"><span class="ml-xs">10 steps you can take to lower your carbon footprint</span></span><svg class="content-box" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 16 16" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" style="transition:right .2s;position:relative;right:4px;fill:#666" aria-hidden="true" focusable="false" role="img"><title>ArrowRight</title><path d="M7.664 1.25l6 data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">Ida is only the latest weather-related disaster in another summer of deadly heat waves, floods, droughts and wildfires, which <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2020/10/22/climate-curious-disasters-climate-change/?itid=lb_more-on-climate-change_3&itid=lk_inline_manual_5">evidence suggests</a> are becoming more frequent and intense due to climate change. <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2021/07/24/amid-summer-fire-floods-moment-truth-climate-action/?itid=lk_inline_manual_5">Scientists say</a> this summer is another sign of what’s to come if the world does not take dramatic steps to curb its use of fossil fuels.</p></div><div class="article-body" data-qa="article-body"><p data-qa="drop-cap-letter" data-el="text" class="font-copy font--article-body gray-darkest ma-0 pb-md">How is climate change affecting the United States? What can be done to address it? Washington Post climate reporters <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/people/sarah-kaplan/?itid=lk_inline_manual_6">Sarah Kaplan</a> and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/people/tik-root/?itid=lk_inline_manual_6">Tik Root</a> answered your questions live. Kaplan covers how humans are responding to a warming world and regularly writes The Post’s <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/2021/01/27/climate-curioius-weatherization/?itid=lk_inline_manual_6" target=_blank>Climate Curious column</a>. Root reports on climate and <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-solutions/?itid=lk_inline_manual_6" target=_blank>climate solutions</a> for The Post.</p></div><div class="article-body" readabilityObject.title: Where’s the safest place to live in the U.S., given the climate change crisis?
readabilityObject.content:
correction

A previous version of this article incorrectly said that congressional Democrats were working on a $3.5 billion reconciliation bill. The proposed bill is $3.5 trillion. The article has been corrected.

When Hurricane Ida made landfall on the coast of Louisiana Sunday, the Category 4 hurricane was one of the most intense storms to hit the state. More than a million people lost power, entire towns were cut from communication and many have been left without clean water — or in some cases, water at all. Human-caused warming of the planet, experts say, likely made the hurricane more powerful than it otherwise would have been.

Ida is only the latest weather-related disaster in another summer of deadly heat waves, floods, droughts and wildfires, which evidence suggests are becoming more frequent and intense due to climate change. Scientists say this summer is another sign of what’s to come if the world does not take dramatic steps to curb its use of fossil fuels.

How is climate change affecting the United States? What can be done to address it? Washington Post climate reporters Sarah Kaplan and Tik Root answered your questions live. Kaplan covers how humans are responding to a warming world and regularly writes The Post’s Climate Curious column. Root reports on climate and climate solutions for The Post.

Below are a few questions they answered:

Send us your question below. The question box includes a space for your name, but this is optional. Your question may be edited for accuracy and clarity.

Looking for more? Read some of this recent climate coverage:

Sign up to get the latest news about climate change, energy and the environment delivered to your inbox every Thursday.

Lizzy Raben and Eliza Goren, editors on The Post’s audience team, produced this Q&A.
